posts.post_content: It's saccing clause really captures the flavor of Phyrexia but its nonetheless way to expensive to be viable in most environments. 6/3 for 6? I thought that magic passed that power point years ago. The regeneration is just to costly to make it viable with the similar, yet way better, cards in circulation.

posts.post_content:
Other then Nils Hamm's amazing art this card is pretty bad. With [Necropedes](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Necropedes) and [Corpse Cur](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Corpse Cur) it might not be too bad but really should either cost less or have a higher toughness.
  
EDIT: I recently started using a deck that has a bunch of creatures that I WANT to die. In that respect this guy is pretty good.

posts.post_content:
There are currently two ![4](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=4&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol) 6/3 creatures: Corrupted Harvester and its better, rarer, granddad [Laquatus's Champion](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Laquatus's Champion).  
Also interesting: each has a ![4](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=4&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol) 3/2 flying counterpart with similar abilities: [Skeletal Kathari](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Skeletal Kathari) and [Soul Scourge](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Soul Scourge).
posts.html:
There are currently two 6/3 creatures: Corrupted Harvester and its better, rarer, granddad Laquatus's Champion.
Also interesting: each has a 3/2 flying counterpart with similar abilities: Skeletal Kathari and Soul Scourge.
